articles.headline: Syrian Leader’s Brother Seen as Enforcer of Crackdown
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad’s brother, Maher, has emerged as a lightning rod of dissent over his control of elite units in the army.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s brother, Maher, has emerged as a lightning rod of dissent over his control of elite units in the army.
articles.lead_paragraph: As reports mount of defections in the Syrian military and the government staggers from the killing of soldiers and police officers in a northern city this week, President Bashar al-Assad may turn increasingly to his brother, Maher, whose elite units in a demoralized army could prove decisive to his government’s survival, activists and analysts say.
articles.byline: By Katherine Zoepf and Anthony Shadid

articles.headline: Fed Wants Priority Put On Deficit
articles.snippet: Ben Bernanke said Tuesday that the pace of recovery “seems likely” to increase during the rest of the year and he continues to see no evidence of enduring inflation despite recent increases in commodities prices.
articles.abstract: Ben Bernanke said Tuesday that the pace of recovery “seems likely” to increase during the rest of the year and he continues to see no evidence of enduring inflation despite recent increases in commodities prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leaders of the Federal Reserve are talking like people ready to sit down and let others take the lead in addressing the nation’s economic problems.

articles.headline: Emerging Nations Warm to Lagarde for I.M.F. Role
articles.snippet: Some of the biggest developing nations seem to see the French finance minister Christine Lagarde as their best bet for increasing their power at the I.M.F.
articles.abstract: Some of the biggest developing nations seem to see the French finance minister Christine Lagarde as their best bet for increasing their power at the I.M.F.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the race for a new leader at the International Monetary Fund moves toward a pivotal deadline this week, the global charm offensive by the French finance minister, Christine Lagarde, appears to be paying off.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: The German Example
articles.snippet: The lessons from Germany’s economy aren’t liberal or conservative. They are both.
articles.abstract: The lessons from Germany’s economy aren’t liberal or conservative. They are both.

articles.headline: In Wisconsin, Legislative Urgency as Recall Threat Looms
articles.snippet: Republicans who control the Wisconsin Legislature have moved quickly on a variety of fronts, perhaps because they could lose control of the State Senate as early as next month.
articles.abstract: Republicans who control the Wisconsin Legislature have moved quickly on a variety of fronts, perhaps because they could lose control of the State Senate as early as next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — The gears of government tend to grind slowly. But in Wisconsin lately they are racing at turbocharged speed.

articles.headline: California Insurer Says It Will Cap Earnings
articles.snippet: Blue Shield of California has come under sharp criticism in recent months for its double-digit rate increases.
articles.abstract: Blue Shield of California has come under sharp criticism in recent months for its double-digit rate increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer that has come under sharp criticism in recent months for its double-digit rate increases, said on Tuesday that it planned to cap its earning and refund the bulk of any excess income to its policyholders.

articles.headline: Weiner Faces Calls to Resign and Tries to Make Amends
articles.snippet: Representative Anthony D. Weiner has spent much of the past 24 hours apologizing as Republicans have called for his resignation and top Democrats have distanced themselves.
articles.abstract: Representative Anthony D. Weiner has spent much of the past 24 hours apologizing as Republicans have called for his resignation and top Democrats have distanced themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York, reeling from revelations of salacious online behavior that threaten his political career, moved rapidly on Tuesday to make amends as Republicans called for his resignation and leading members of his own Democratic Party distanced themselves from him.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and David W. Chen

articles.headline: Fleeing to Foreign Shores
articles.snippet: Some American start-ups are going abroad to raise capital because domestic markets aren’t available to them.
articles.abstract: Some American start-ups are going abroad to raise capital because domestic markets aren’t available to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reva Medical, a maker of medical devices in San Diego, wanted to go public last year to raise money to satisfy impatient venture capitalists and finance research for its heart stents.

articles.headline: RSA Faces Angry Users After Breach
articles.snippet: Companies rushed to accept an offer from RSA Security to replace SecurID tokens, used to safeguard access to computer networks, after RSA admitted the tokens’ vulnerability.
articles.abstract: Companies rushed to accept an offer from RSA Security to replace SecurID tokens, used to safeguard access to computer networks, after RSA admitted the tokens’ vulnerability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks and large technology companies like SAP rushed Tuesday to accept RSA Security’s offer to replace their ubiquitous SecurID tokens as many computer security experts voiced frustration with the company.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Familiar TV Anchors Move On, Hoping to Profit on Their Own
articles.snippet: The departure of a large class of prominent television personalities is creating upheaval on the small screen and in broadcasting boardrooms.
articles.abstract: The departure of a large class of prominent television personalities is creating upheaval on the small screen and in broadcasting boardrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s enough breaking news to make even an anchorman’s head spin.

articles.headline: Split by Infighting, OPEC Keeps a Cap on Oil
articles.snippet: Over the objections of Saudi Arabia, OPEC decided to maintain its crude oil output levels and might meet again within three months to discuss increasing production.
articles.abstract: Over the objections of Saudi Arabia, OPEC decided to maintain its crude oil output levels and might meet again within three months to discuss increasing production.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ended on Wednesday in disarray, with ministers failing to reach a consensus to raise oil production levels. That left existing quotas in place, despite rising world prices and pressure from major oil-consuming countries to increase output.
